summary: This is a Bureau of Prisons Psychological Reconstruction Report on the death by suicide of inmate Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Complex (MCC) New York on August 10, 2019. The report details Epstein's background, institutional history, mental health assessments, and the circumstances leading to his death. It identifies numerous procedural failures, inconsistencies in documentation, and staff errors, and provides recommendations for corrective actions. The report is an interim document due to an inability to gather all data, as the FBI had confiscated key evidence.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide on August 10, 2019, while in pretrial custody at MCC New York on federal sex trafficking charges.

The psychological reconstruction was severely limited because the FBI had confiscated the original video footage of the incident, and formal interviews were not conducted to avoid interfering with other DOJ investigations.
On July 23, 2019, Epstein was found with a cloth around his neck in an incident initially reported as a possible suicide attempt; he later denied it and claimed his cellmate tried to kill him.

Significant procedural failures were identified, including failure to complete proper 30-minute rounds, inaccurate SENTRY cell assignments, documentation errors, and a lack of direct observation during attorney visits while on suicide watch.

On August 9, 2019, the day before his death, approximately 2,000 pages of court documents containing graphic allegations against Epstein were unsealed, which the report suggests contributed to his distress.
